item.title: Time Series
item.description: Here is the instruction how to make Time Series. Like everywhere, first we have to install the pakages: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) In this example we want to see Babe Ruth’s homeruns over his career in baseball. query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) Now we want to make the paragraf, and for that we need ggplot2: ggplot()+ geom_line(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ geom_point(data=result,aes(x=yearID,y=HR))+ ggtitle("Ruth's Homerans Totals Trough the Years")+ xlab("Year")+ ylab("Homeruns")

item.title: Bar Plot
item.description: Here we can see how to make ourown Bar Plot! First step is to install all the pakages: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) In this example we will look at the team homerun totals for all the MLB teams in 1980: query<-"SELECT name,HR FROM Teams WHERE yearID=1980 ORDER BY HR" result<-sqldf(query) result$name<-factor(result$name,levels=result$name) To make an bar plot, we have to use this command! But aslo we can play with sizes of bins and otehr colors!

item.title: Histogram
item.description: Here you can see how to make an Histagram! In this example we want to see the weights of MLB players, through the Master table. But firstly, we have to install those pakages: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) For this example, we need to use the Master table to gather its data. query<-"SELECT weight FROM Master" result<-sqldf(query) Also, we have to use handy tool ggplot2: ggplot()+ geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight),color="purple",fill="white",bins=50)+ ggtitle("Body-weight Distribution for Baseball Players")+ xlab("Weight of player")+ ylab("Number of players") ## Warning: Removed 854 rows containing non-finite values (stat_bin).

item.title: Scatterplot
item.description: Here we can see how to make our own Scatterplot! First, we have to install the following pakages: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) When we installed the pakages, we are going to find the career of homeruns and strikeouts from players who had more than 400 homeruns. query<-"SELECT playerID,sum(HR) AS career_HR,sum(SO) AS career_so FROM Batting GROUP BY playerID HAVING sum(HR)>=400" result<-sqldf(query) To make a graph we would have to use ggplot2. You can also use diffrent colors and sizes.
